28.text: So, who is this guy then?

33.text: It is pronounced St John or Sinjun? Lucy can you find out?

38.text: He’s related to Lucinda Meldrum, stepson maybe. They were close.

49.text: Yeah, well, so are they all. What’s so important about him?

54.text: That's what we're here to find out

62.text: People are, I don’t know, intimidated by him

66.text: And I want to find out why

68.text: The thing I don’t know is why he wanted to meet in Parliament

74.text: He must have friends in high places

105.text: Thank you for joining us today, Mr St John

110.text: Our viewers are very interested in getting to know you. You’re a bit of a mystery to the British public.

117.text: Why don’t you tell us a little about what you do?

122.text: I'm a businessman. A financier, you might say.

128.text: Not exactly. I provide advice to various entities.

142.text: That changes every day. I help out when I can.

148.text: You were a close associate of Lucinda Meldrum, I understand

152.text: I was at one time, but things change

156.text: You're related to her, I believe?

158.text: I'm her stepson. I grew up with her. I guess you could say she raised me.

166.text: - What happened to your own mother?

172.text: Is this what you’ve come to talk to me about? My parents?

176.text: No, no, we’re just trying to establish a few facts. You see we know very little about you.

181.text: And yet your name comes up so often in records at parliamentary meetings

193.text:
Well, I’m a very busy man, Jeremy.
Fingers in a lot of pies, as the saying goes.

200.text: People say you make things happen

203.text: Well that’s what I’m here for

205.text: People also say you push your weight around. That you’re an intimidating figure.

219.text: Jeremy, without names, they’re not real

228.text: You have a lot of power for a man no one’s ever heard of. You operate in the shadows.

236.text: That’s a paranoid way to put it. I operate exactly where I’m needed.

241.text: You weren’t elected to Parliament and yet I’m told you have offices here. That you treat MPs like staff.

247.text: Jeremy, I’m a consultant. I have to be near my clients.

254.text: So, you’re an unelected man of tremendous means with offices at the heart of the British government

272.text: What exactly does your work involve?

279.text: I work closely with ministers on matters of public policy, particularly those that impact business

288.text: I ensure that new laws don’t adversely impact corporate activity

299.text: Some might say you don’t belong here. That you’re an interloper in the British democratic system.

313.text: An unelected freeloader clinging parasitically to the intestinal wall of Parliament

324.text: What would you say to those people?

338.text: Their system of government is inefficient, indulgent

353.text: You can’t have a government run by 60 million people

357.text: Without someone like myself to step up and ensure that it operates in a manner that’s fair to business

364.text: And the need for economic growth, the whole thing would fall apart in a matter of months

370.text: Oh, people think they control the government through their votes and that’s fine with me

376.text: I’m here behind the scenes to make sure that the system really works and that the money keeps flowing

383.text: I’m the reality here, Jeremy. Me.

394.text: Oh I most certainly do. It’s a very useful sham.

400.text: A handy pretence to make everyone believe that they actually have any say at all

408.text: Over what goes on in this place

413.text: Jeremy, if they think they have a say, they’re quiet. Docile.

420.text: And that allows me to get on with my work

424.text: So you’re saying that the entire system, Prime Minister’s questions, everything, is fake?

435.text: That when you really get down to it, the person in charge is you?

447.text: One more question. People say that you had something to do with what happened to Lucinda Meldrum.

458.text: I’ve indulged you long enough, Jeremy

461.text: You have no idea the power I have

466.text: If you walk out of this building alive today it will be because I said it was fine for you to do so

474.text: If you make it home safely tonight, it will be because I want that to happen

483.text: You do not have free will, Jeremy.

497.text: Did he just threaten me? Did you hear that?

500.text: I don't feel good about this

508.text: Sir, we need you to come with us

515.text: Shut up. Just shut up. Shut up.

531.text: This is Gabe. It's taken care of.
